Award.AwardTitle: MRI Consortium: Acquisition of a Heterogeneous, Shared, Computing Instrument to Enable Science and Computing Research by the Mass. Green High Performance Computing Consortium

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This work includes a consortium acquisition of a shared high-performance computing (HPC) instrument emphasizing HPC-based science and engineering with the benefit of "on-demand" capabilities. The instrument is a hybrid platform, integrating a state-of-the-art cluster computer with forward-looking, potentially exascale-oriented, GPU accelerator hardware that will enable progress in key STEM applications across a consortium of higher-educational partners with a research agenda that spans science disciplines.

The system?s high levels of responsiveness will be applied to systems modeling and identification for immunology, interactive drug pathway analysis, bio-molecular electrostatics, virtual earth modeling and data analysis, multi-scale environment modeling, adaptive real-time model data synthesis, interactive virtualized materials design, and studying fundamental physics of matter. In computer science, researchers and industry collaborators will use the instrument as a controlled, configurable facility with an advanced user base and application workload, driving forward research into abstractions for next-generation HPC environments, enhanced virtualization methodologies for large-scale HPC, and quantitatively experimenting in cloud/service paradigms at scale for HPC.

The acquisition will catalyze collaboration among scientists, engineers, computational science practitioners and computer scientists with research interests in
- broadening the use of HPC for critical science and engineering problems
- driving knowledge in earth science, life science, material science and basic physics
- developing new, more engaging approaches to HPC
- paving the way for a post-petascale HPC ecosystem spanning software to workforce skills
- ere are extensive education and outreach activities planned to grow participation across institutional research communities as well as among local collaborators at community colleges, in K-12 education, and in community organizations.

The instrument will contribute to cyberinfrastructure in multiple ways and will be a valuable part of a broader public-private partnership enhancing computational science infrastructure and catalyzing high-tech innovation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award supported the deployment and commissioning of computional resources to support research at Boston University, Harvard University, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Northeastern University and the University of Massachusetts. The research supported has covered many disciplines including life-science, Earth science, fusion research, economics and computer science. In the area of Intellectual Merit domain research results from the projects contributed to many activities, including

  • high-impact basic science (for example the LIGO gravitational wave consortium made use of the resources) 

and applied research into, for example,

  • high-impact studies for next generation fusion systems (for example efforts that may lead to a major US led advance in commercial fusion energy) , 
  • next generation health-care databases (for example analysis for a next generation heart health diagnostics tool that is used throughout the world) and 
  • political sciences (for example studies of the governance patterns and economic output globally)

In the area of Intellectual Merit in computational infrastructure the project has developed approaches that facilitate the use of a cluster resource by groups with very different software needs and working practices. These have been very effective in accomodating growth in innovative statistical methods from the machine learning community. A particular focus of innovation in this regard has been in interactive environments for highly parallel computing.

In Broader Impacts the project pioneered developing regional collaboration in support of large-scale computational research infrastructure. This helped cement academic and organizational relationships around the Massachusetts Green High-Performance Computing Center (MGHPCC) in the US Northeast. The MGHPCC is one of the largest cyberinfrastructure collaborations in the region. This NSF project was the first activity involving the MGHPCC to actively demonstrate the potential of developing shared, collaborative computing environments for researchers across multiple unversities in the region. This activity has benefited many institutions in the region and has postively impacted the economy of Holyoke, Masschusetts a former mill town with high unemployment. The NSF project has catalyzed paid technology appenticeships with community college students from Holyoke, MA. Most apprentices have gone on to 4-year colleges or full-time work in technology industry.
